3624510229.resolved_title: Notes From the Inner Lives of Con Artists

10.caption: Nick PachelliNick Pachelli is an editor at Truly*Adventurous. He’s written on crimes, cons, and more for a number of publications, including The Guardian, The New York Times, Slate, and others. A proud lifelong New Mexican, he feels somewhat guilty about the fact that he doesn’t really like Santa Fe at all.

3830610955.resolved_title: How a Team of Ambitious Crooks in 1960s Montreal Planned the Biggest Bank Heist Anyone Had Ever Seen
3830610955.excerpt: In the spring of 1961, Georges Lemay, a dapper thirty-six-year-old French Canadian, spent his days holed up in his cottage on a private island on a river in the Laurentian Mountains north of Montreal, devising his greatest feat yet: the perfect bank burglary.

3344919826.given_title: 11 of the Greatest Scams of All Time, Curated by ‘Scam Goddess’ Laci Mosley
3344919826.resolved_title: 11 of the Greatest Scams of All Time, Curated by ‘Scam Goddess’ Laci Mosley

12.caption: Laci MosleyLaci Mosley is an American actress, comedian, and podcaster from Dallas, Texas. She performs improv comedy at UCB Los Angeles and co-starred in the Pop comedy series Florida Girls. Mosley is best known for her podcast Scam Goddess, which focuses on historical and contemporary scams and cons with a comedic twist. Follow her on Instagram and Twitter.

3325376097.resolved_title: Three Family Members, One Business. Robbing Armored Cars.
3325376097.excerpt: A man returns home from the army and gets a surprising offer from his father: Join the family business and help mom & pop pull off a string of daring cross-country heists. No one expects the betrayals coming.

3694174899.resolved_title: What Canada’s Largest Art Heist Reveals about the Art World’s Shady Side
3694174899.excerpt: By all accounts, the biggest art heist in Canadian history should’ve been even bigger. Just past midnight on September 4, 1972—fifty years ago, this month—a man in a ski mask and climbing spurs accessed the roof of the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts by scaling a nearby tree.

4005459993.given_title: How a Nuclear Weapons Lab Helped Crack a Serial-Killer Case
4005459993.resolved_title: How a Nuclear Weapons Lab Helped Crack a Serial-Killer Case
4005459993.excerpt: Nuclear weapons laboratories don’t often help solve serial-killer cases. But in the investigation of Efren Saldivar, data from such a lab provided the clinching evidence that led to his conviction on six counts of murder.

1.caption: WHAT I LEFT OUT is a recurring feature in which book authors are invited to share anecdotes and narratives that, for whatever reason, did not make it into their final manuscripts. In this installment, Sarah Scoles shares a story that didn’t make it into her recent book “Countdown: The Blinding Future of Nuclear Weapons”

2.caption: Forensic Science Center chemist Eddie Salazar performs solid-phase extraction to isolate a spiked chemical during a proficiency test for the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons in 2021. The same extraction technique was used by the center to identify Pavulon in Efren Saldivar’s victims. Visual: Lawrence Livermore National Lab

3815095960.resolved_title: How the Biggest Fraud in German History Unravelled
3815095960.excerpt: Late in the spring of 2020, Jan Marsalek, an Austrian bank executive, was suspended from his job. He was a widely admired figure in the European business community—charismatic, trilingual, and well travelled.

2.caption: “Next time, could you not use your podcast voice?”

3.caption: “Don’t pause it—just let me ask you questions for the next twenty minutes.”

5.caption: “He has this crazy conspiracy theory about object permanence.”

6.caption: “He’s perfect, but he lives all the way on the other side of the apple.”

9.caption: Marsalek, who held eight passports, escaped to Moscow. His last known phone activity was last year.

4003684428.given_title: A Teen’s Fatal Plunge Into the London Underworld
4003684428.resolved_title: A Teen’s Fatal Plunge Into the London Underworld
4003684428.excerpt: After Zac Brettler died, his parents struggled to decode the mystery of what had happened to him. They thought that they could pinpoint the moment he’d started to change: three years earlier, when, at sixteen, he began boarding at Mill Hill School, in North London.

2.caption: “Hon, do you think it’s time you took a break from the light-therapy lamp?”

4.caption: Police recovered an iPad among Zac’s belongings, and discovered that two days before he died he had done an Internet search for “witness protection uk.”

5.caption: “The assignment was three full pages without illuminated drop caps, Chauncey.”

6.caption: “It’s too late for Greg. The tchotchkes have him now.”

7.caption: Rachelle and Matthew Brettler. Although they were unaware that Zac had been code-switching between two identities, Matthew says that his son always had “a slightly preternatural ability to tell stories.”

8.caption: “Now I’m going to tell you about the passenger who didn’t put their tray in the upright and locked position.”

4015420240.given_title: In Ancient Bones, a Reminder that Northern Ireland’s Ghosts Are Never Far
4015420240.resolved_title: In Ancient Bones, a Reminder That Northern Ireland’s Ghosts Are Never Far
4015420240.excerpt: They turned up around Halloween, as a roaring storm gripped the wetlands of Northern Ireland and tilled its ground: human bones, sticking up from the tea-colored water in Bellaghy bog, halfway between Derry and Belfast. The skeletal remains were disconcerting enough.

3794011395.given_title: The Spectacular Case of Lørenskog: Norway's Ongoing Search for a Murderer
3794011395.resolved_title: The Spectacular Case of Lørenskog Norway's Hunt for a Murderer
3794011395.excerpt: Anne-Elisabeth Hagen, 68, was married to one of the wealthiest men in Norway. But four years ago, she disappeared, and police still have no solid leads. The entire country has been obsessed by the case ever since. On December 6, 2018, 29-year-old Ole Henrik Golf deboards a plane in Oslo.

3374712819.given_title: “The Only Thing I Knew How to Do Was Kill People”: Inside the Rash of Unexp
3374712819.resolved_title: “The Only Thing I Knew How to Do Was Kill People”: Inside the Rash of Unexplained Deaths at Fort Hood
3374712819.excerpt: The numbers are distressing. Last year, at least 39 Fort Hood soldiers died or went missing. Thirteen killed themselves. Five were murdered. Eleven of the deaths remain unresolved—some legally; others for the victims’ families.

3927561387.given_title: Kyle Deschanel, the Rothschild Who Wasn’t
3927561387.resolved_title: Kyle Deschanel, the Rothschild Who Wasn’t
3927561387.excerpt: There’s a three-story, three-bedroom town house at 514 Broome Street in Manhattan with an expansive ivy-laden terrace. Entry is through a dining room swathed in exposed brick. A dramatic wooden staircase services the second floor.

1.caption: The DeckKyle Deschanel, the Rothschild Who Wasn’tWhen Kyle de Rothschild Deschanel arrived in New York nightlife and venture fundraising circles a few years ago, he was an instant hit. Equal parts charm, enterprise, and fabulous family wealth, he seemed to live on a 24/7 carousel of mega-dollar deals and raucous parties. It was almost as if he had conjured his entire existence out of thin air. What if he had?By August 30, 2023

2.caption: A screenshot of a story post from Deschanel’s now-deleted Instagram account, @degeneratesnoopy.Photo credit: anonymous.

3.caption: Kyle Deschanel at the launch of a new line by the jewelry designer Jack Vartanian in 2015, with Ashton Randle.Samantha Deitch/BFA.com.

4.caption: Deschanel in March 2023, at a party for the anniversary of The Flower Shop. With Bambi Northwood-Blyth, center, and Frank Gibbs.David X Prutting/BFA.com.

5.caption: Clockwise from top left: Deschanel’s face on a Global Entry card issued to an Aryeh Dodelson; Deschanel at home with a small dog; Deschanel with Cochran; Deschanel’s gold American Express Business card for Oxshott Capital-related expenses; Deschanel at the annual Halloween party at the Boom Boom Room at the Standard.Photo credits: anonymous.

6.caption: Deschanel opening a bottle of Pol Roger Brut Réserve at his home on Broome Street in Soho.Photo credit: anonymous.

7.credit: Vincent Tullo/The New York Times/Redux (The Nines)
7.caption: From left: Deschanel taking a look at the menu at Cipriani Downtown; the main dining room at The Nines, a swanky piano bar on Great Jones Street.Vincent Tullo/The New York Times/Redux

8.caption: Deschanel with Christina Cochran, right, and Gretta Bannister-Hopkins.
